1.title: Simple Present
1.content:
The Simple Present is used to describe habits, general truths, repeated actions, or unchanging situations, emotions, and wishes.

Structure:

Subject + Base Verb (+s/es)

Examples:

  • This function returns an array of objects.
  • We have a daily stand-up meeting at 9 AM.
  • Does the script run automatically?

2.title: Subject Questions
2.content:
A Subject Question asks about the doer or performer of an action. The question word (like Who, What, or Which) is the subject of the sentence.

The key rule is that we do not use auxiliary verbs (do, does, did) in simple present and simple past tenses. The sentence structure is like a normal statement.

Structure:

Question Word (Subject) + Main Verb + (Object)?

Examples:

  • Who implemented this feature?
  • What causes this conflict?
  • Which team has the latest code?

3.title: Object Questions
3.content:
An Object Question asks about the receiver of an action. The subject is known, and the question word asks about the object.

The key rule is that we must use auxiliary verbs (do, does, did) in simple present and simple past tenses. The structure requires inversion.

Structure:

Question Word (Object) + Auxiliary Verb + Subject + Main Verb?

Examples:

  • What module did the team modify?
  • Who did you ask?
  • Which report does this change mention?

4.title: Negative Questions
4.content:
Negative questions are used to confirm something you think is true, or to express surprise. They are very common in conversation.

They are usually formed with a contracted auxiliary verb (e.g., Don't, Isn't, Shouldn't, Didn't) at the beginning.

Structure:

Negative Auxiliary + Subject + Main Verb?

Examples:

  • Don't you think this is too complex?
  • Shouldn't this feature be in production?
  • Didn't we fix this issue already?

5.title: Present Perfect
5.content:
The Present Perfect connects the past with the present. It's used for actions that happened at an unspecified time in the past or actions that started in the past and continue to the present.

It focuses on the result or relevance of the action now, not when it happened.

Structure:

Subject + have/has + Past Participle

Examples:

  • I have finished my part of the project.
  • She has worked here for five years.
  • Have you seen the latest design mockups?

6.title: Present Perfect Continuous
6.content:
The Present Perfect Continuous is used for an action that started in the past and is still in progress now, or has very recently stopped.

It emphasizes the duration of the action.

Structure:

Subject + have/has been + Verb-ing

Examples:

  • I have been trying to solve this bug all day.
  • The team has been developing this feature since last month.
  • He has been working late, so he looks tired.

7.title: Past Perfect
7.content:
The Past Perfect is used to talk about an action that happened before another action in the past. It clarifies the sequence of events.

Think of it as the 'past of the past'.

Structure:

Subject + had + Past Participle

Examples:

  • The system crashed after we had deployed the changes.
  • By the time they responded, I had found a solution.
  • He had already left when I arrived.

8.title: First Conditional
8.content:
The First Conditional is used to talk about real and possible future situations. It describes a likely result if a certain condition is met.

Structure:

If + Present Simple, ... will + Base Verb

Examples:

  • If we finish early, we will deploy the update.
  • If the server goes down, I will call you immediately.
  • You will miss the deadline if you don't start now.
  • She will be late if the train is delayed.
  • If I have time later, I 'll call you.
  • Will you help me if I need it?

9.title: Second Conditional
9.content:
The Second Conditional is used for hypothetical or unlikely situations in the present or future. It describes an imaginary result for an unreal condition.

Structure:

If + Past Simple, ... would + Base Verb

Examples:

  • If I had more time, I would refactor this module.
  • If we had the budget, we would hire another developer.
  • What would you do if you were the project manager?
  • If I were you, I would take the job.
  • Morale would improve if the company gave everyone a bonus.
  • We would travel more if we didn't have kids.

10.title: Third Conditional
10.content:
The Third Conditional is used to talk about hypothetical situations in the past. It describes an imaginary result for a past condition that did not happen. It's often used to express regret.

Structure:

If + Past Perfect, ... would have + Past Participle

Examples:

  • If I had known about the bug, I would have fixed it.
  • If we had tested it better, the system would not have crashed.
  • They would have finished on time if the requirements hadn't changed.
  • If you had told me, I would have helped you.
  • She wouldn't have been so tired if she had gone to bed earlier.
  • Would you have accepted the offer if they had offered more money?

11.title: Modal Perfects
11.content:
Modal Perfects (modal + have + past participle) are used to speculate, judge, or discuss possibilities and unfulfilled actions in the past. They allow us to express how we feel about a past event.

Breakdown of Meanings:

  • Should have: Expresses regret or criticism about a past action. It was the 'right' thing to do, but it didn't happen.
  • Could have: Expresses an unrealized past possibility or opportunity. The action was possible, but it wasn't taken.
  • Must have / Can't have: Expresses a logical deduction. 'Must have' for high certainty something happened; 'Can't have' for high certainty it did not.
  • Would have: Used for the result of a hypothetical past condition (3rd Conditional) or a past willingness that was not acted upon.
  • Might / May have: Expresses a past possibility with less certainty than 'must have'.

Structure:

Subject + modal + have + Past Participle

Examples:

  • (Regret) I should have saved my work before the computer crashed.
  • (Criticism) You shouldn't have deployed without running the tests.
  • (Possibility) We could have finished yesterday, but we ran into an issue.
  • (Deduction +) The server is down. Someone must have restarted it.
  • (Deduction -) He can't have finished already; he only started an hour ago.
  • (Conditional) If I had known, I would have helped you.
  • (Speculation) She's late. She might have gotten stuck in traffic.
  • (Past Willingness) I would have joined the meeting, but I had another commitment.
  • (Lost Opportunity) You could have caused a major system failure with that command.
  • (Uncertain Possibility) The data corruption may have been a network error, but we're not sure.

12.title: The Passive Voice
12.content:
The Passive Voice is used when the focus is on the action or the receiver of the action, not on the person who performs it (the agent).

It is very common in technical and formal writing.

Structure:

Object + be (conjugated) + Past Participle

Examples:

  • The new feature was implemented last week.
  • The server is being restarted now.
  • This report must be finished by tomorrow.

13.title: Gerunds (-ing) vs. Infinitives (to + verb)
13.content:
Whether you use a gerund or an infinitive after a verb depends on the main verb.

Gerunds (-ing) are used after verbs like 'enjoy', 'avoid', 'finish'. Infinitives (to + verb) are used after verbs like 'want', 'need', 'decide'.

Structure:

Subject + Main Verb + Gerund / Infinitive

Examples:

  • We should avoid deploying on a Friday.
  • I decided to refactor the entire class.
  • She suggested using a different library.

14.title: Gerunds after Prepositions
14.content:
This is a very consistent rule in English: if a verb follows a preposition (in, on, at, for, about, without, etc.), the verb must be in its gerund (-ing) form.

This rule also applies to phrasal verbs that end in a preposition, like 'look forward to'.

Structure:

... Preposition + Verb-ing

Examples:

  • Thank you for helping me with the setup.
  • We can't move forward without approving the budget.
  • I'm looking forward to seeing the final product.

15.title: Used to vs. Be used to
15.content:
These two expressions are easily confused but have completely different meanings and grammatical structures.

used to + base verb refers to a past habit or state that is no longer true. be used to + gerund (-ing) means to be familiar with or accustomed to something.

Examples (Present Context - 'be used to'):

  • He is a chef, so he is used to working under pressure.
  • After three months, I am finally used to waking up early.
  • They live near the airport, so they are used to the noise.
  • She isn't used to using this software yet.
  • Are you used to driving in the city now?

Examples (Past Context - 'used to'):

  • I used to live in a small town.
  • We used to play outside for hours when we were kids.
  • She didn't use to like coffee, but now she loves it.
  • He used to have long hair.
  • Did you use to work with him at your old company?

16.title: Phrasal Verbs
16.content:
A Phrasal Verb is a combination of a verb and a particle (a preposition or adverb). The meaning of this combination is often idiomatic and very different from the individual words. Mastering them is essential for sounding natural in English.

Some phrasal verbs are separable, meaning an object can go in the middle (e.g., 'turn the light off').

Common Examples:

  • Give up (to quit/stop trying)
    Don't give up on your goals.
  • Take off (to leave the ground; to remove clothing)
    The plane will take off in five minutes.
  • Look after (to take care of)
    Can you look after my cat this weekend?
  • Run out of (to exhaust a supply)
    We ran out of milk this morning.
  • Put up with (to tolerate)
    I can't put up with that noise anymore.
  • Turn down (to reject an offer; to lower volume)
    She had to turn down the job offer.
  • Get over (to recover from an illness or disappointment)
    It took him a long time to get over the breakup.
  • Break down (to stop functioning)
    My car broke down on the highway.

17.title: False Friends
17.content:
False Friends are words in two languages that look similar but have different meanings. They are a common source of mistakes.

Structure:

N/A (Lexical, not grammatical structure)

Examples:

  • He will assist (help) you, so you must attend (asistir a) the meeting.
  • 'Actually' (in fact) is not the same as 'actualmente' (currently).
  • A 'library' (biblioteca) is not a 'librería' (bookstore).

18.title: Make vs. Do
18.content:
While both verbs relate to actions, they are not interchangeable. The key difference lies in the outcome of the action.

When to use DO

Use DO for tasks, obligations, and general activities that do not produce a new physical object.

  • Work, jobs, or repetitive tasks.
  • General, non-specific activities.
  • Household chores.

When to use MAKE

Use MAKE for actions related to creating, producing, or causing a result or reaction.

  • Creating a physical object.
  • Producing a sound, reaction, or effect.
  • Plans and decisions.

Common Examples

DO:

  • We need to [do business] with that new client.
  • Could you [do me a favor] and review this code?
  • I have to [do the laundry] this afternoon.
  • She always encourages me to [do my best].
  • You should [do some research] before the meeting.

MAKE:

  • The team needs to [make a decision] by Friday.
  • He was asked to [make a suggestion] to improve the workflow.
  • I have to [make a phone call] before we start.
  • Try not to [make a mistake] in the final report.
  • This new feature will [make a big difference].

19.title: Modal Verbs: Future Equivalents
19.content:
Modal verbs like can, must, and may do not have future tenses. To express these ideas in the future, we use their equivalent phrasal forms.

Structure:

will + be able to / have to / be allowed to

Examples:

  • After the update, you will be able to export the data.
  • You will have to update your password next week.
  • Users won't be allowed to access this section.

20.title: Possessive Nouns ('s)
20.content:
To show that something belongs to a noun, we usually add an apostrophe + s ('s). For plural nouns ending in -s, we just add an apostrophe.

Structure:

Noun + 's / s' + Noun

Examples:

  • We need to check the issue's history.
  • Where is tomorrow's meeting agenda?
  • This is the developers' main repository.

21.title: Prepositions of Time: In, On, At
21.content:
Choosing the correct preposition for time expressions follows general rules: IN for long periods (months, years), ON for specific days/dates, and AT for specific times.

Structure:

IN [Month/Year] | ON [Day/Date] | AT [Time]

Examples:

  • The release is scheduled in August.
  • The meeting is on Friday.
  • Let's sync at 3:00 PM.

22.title: Prepositions of Place: In, On, At
22.content:
These prepositions also refer to location: IN for enclosed spaces/large areas, ON for surfaces, and AT for specific points.

Structure:

IN [Enclosed Space] | ON [Surface] | AT [Point]

Examples:

  • The connection string is in the configuration file.
  • The logo is on the main page.
  • Let's meet at the whiteboard.

23.title: Adjective vs. Adverb
23.content:
An adjective describes a noun (e.g., 'good'). An adverb describes a verb, an adjective, or another adverb (e.g., 'well').

Structure:

Adjective + Noun | Verb + Adverb

Examples:

  • He is a good developer.
  • He develops well.
  • The code is extremely slow. ('extremely' modifies 'slow')

24.title: Still vs. Yet
24.content:
Still is used for actions that continue, often in positive sentences. Yet is for expected actions that haven't happened, used in negative sentences and questions.

Structure:

(+) ... still ... | (-) ... not ... yet. | (?) ... yet?

Examples:

  • We are still working on the issue.
  • We haven't fixed it yet.
  • Have you deployed the changes yet?

25.title: So vs. Such
25.content:
Both are used for emphasis. So is followed by an adjective or adverb. Such is followed by a noun or an adjective + noun.

Structure:

so + adj/adv | such + (a/an) + (adj) + noun

Examples:

  • The process was so complicated.
  • It was such a complicated process.
  • He codes so quickly.

26.title: Ago vs. For
26.content:
Ago is used with the Past Simple for a finished action at a specific time before now. For is often used with the Present Perfect to describe the duration of an action.

Structure:

Past Simple ... [time] ago. | Present Perfect ... for [duration].

Examples:

  • I started this job three years ago.
  • I have worked here for three years.
  • We deployed the last version two weeks ago.

27.title: Comparatives and Superlatives
27.content:
We use comparatives to compare two things (-er or 'more'). We use superlatives to compare three or more things (-est or 'the most').

Structure:

Adj-er than / more Adj than | the Adj-est / the most Adj

Examples:

  • This API is faster than the old one.
  • This is the most difficult task in the project.
  • Python is easier to learn than C++.

28.title: Adjective Order
28.content:
When using multiple adjectives to describe a noun, they usually follow a specific order. A common guide is OSASCOMP: Opinion, Size, Age, Shape, Color, Origin, Material, Purpose.

Structure:

Determiner + Opinion + Size + Age ... + Noun

Examples:

  • We need an efficient new American system.
  • They are using a big old server.
  • It is a small plastic component.

29.title: Countable vs. Uncountable Nouns
29.content:
Countable nouns can be counted (one bug, two bugs) and use 'many' or 'a few'. Uncountable nouns cannot be counted (information, software) and use 'much' or 'a little'.

Structure:

many/few + Countable | much/little + Uncountable

Examples:

  • How many tickets are open?
  • How much progress have we made?
  • We need a little more information before we start.

30.title: Articles: A/An vs. The
30.content:
A/An is an indefinite article used for general, non-specific nouns. The is a definite article used for specific nouns known to the speaker and listener.

Structure:

A/An + singular countable noun (general) | The + noun (specific)

Examples:

  • We need a solution. (Any solution).
  • We need the solution we discussed. (A specific one).
  • It uses an algorithm to sort the data.

31.title: Zero Article (No Article)
31.content:
Sometimes, no article is needed. This 'zero article' is used when speaking about things in general with plural or uncountable nouns.

Structure:

No article with general plural/uncountable nouns.

Examples:

  • Software development is a complex field.
  • Bugs are inevitable in any project.
  • We use encryption to protect data.

32.title: Too vs. Enough
32.content:
Too indicates an excess (negative meaning). Enough indicates a sufficient amount (positive/neutral meaning).

Structure:

too + adj/adv | adj/adv + enough | enough + noun

Examples:

  • This task is too difficult to finish today.
  • This server is not powerful enough.
  • We don't have enough time to test everything.

33.title: Connectors of Contrast
33.content:
These words connect contrasting ideas. Although/Even though are followed by a clause. Despite/In spite of are followed by a noun or gerund. However connects two sentences.

Structure:

Although + clause | Despite + noun/-ing

Examples:

  • Although the code works, it is not efficient.
  • Despite the problems, we launched on time.
  • The plan is good. However, we lack the resources.

34.title: Relative Clauses (who, which, that)
34.content:
A Relative Clause adds extra information about a noun. Use who for people, which for things, and that for both (in defining clauses).

Structure:

... Noun + who/which/that + Verb ...

Examples:

  • The developer who wrote this code is on vacation.
  • This is the bug which is blocking the release.
  • She is the expert that we need to consult.

35.title: Question Tags
35.content:
A Question Tag is a short question at the end of a statement to ask for confirmation. A positive statement gets a negative tag, and vice-versa.

Structure:

Statement, auxiliary + pronoun?

Examples:

  • The deployment was successful, wasn't it?
  • You have tested this feature, haven't you?
  • He can't access the server, can he?

36.title: Get + Adjective
36.content:
The verb get is often used with an adjective to express a change of state. It is a dynamic alternative to 'become'.

Structure:

Subject + get (conjugated) + Adjective

Examples:

  • I am getting tired of these repetitive tasks.
  • The situation got complicated very quickly.
  • Don't get angry, it's just a minor issue.

37.title: Had Better
37.content:
Had better ('d better) is a modal expression used to give strong advice or a warning. It implies negative consequences if the advice is not followed.

Despite using 'had', it refers to the present or immediate future.

Structure:

Subject + 'd better + Base Verb

Examples:

  • You'd better submit that report before the deadline.
  • We'd better not break the build again.
  • He'd better call the client back immediately.

38.title: Be Supposed To
38.content:
The expression be supposed to is used to talk about what is expected, arranged, or intended to happen. It often implies that the reality is different from the expectation.

Structure:

Subject + be (conjugated) + supposed to + Base Verb

Examples:

  • This API key is supposed to give us admin access.
  • I was supposed to finish this yesterday.
  • The meeting is supposed to start at 10 AM.

39.title: Causative Verbs (let, make, have, get)
39.content:
Causative Verbs express an action that one person causes another to do. The structure varies: let/make/have someone do something, but get someone to do something.

Structure:

Subject + Causative + Agent + Verb

Examples:

  • The manager let me leave early.
  • He made me rewrite the entire document.
  • I can't get this code to work.

40.title: Wish / If Only
40.content:
We use wish and if only to express regrets or desires for things to be different. The verb tense 'shifts back': use Past Simple for present wishes, and Past Perfect for past regrets.

Structure:

Subject + wish + Subject + Past Simple/Perfect

Examples:

  • I wish I had more time to complete this. (Present wish).
  • He wishes he knew the answer. (Present wish).
  • I wish I had saved my work more often. (Past regret).

41.title: Would Rather ('d rather)
41.content:
Would rather (contracted to 'd rather) is used to express a preference for one option over another in a specific situation, not as a general habit. The grammatical structure that follows is key.

Main Structures:

1. Own Preference:
Subject + 'd rather + Base Verb

2. Comparing Options:
S. + 'd rather + [Verb A] + than + [Verb B]

3. Preference about someone else's action (Subjunctive):
S1 + 'd rather + S2 + Past Simple Verb

Key Differences: 'Would Rather' vs. 'Prefer'

Although they express preference, their usage and grammar are different. Understanding this is fundamental.

  • Prefer: Used for general preferences or habits. It's what you like in general.
    I prefer working from home to going to the office.
  • Would Prefer: For specific preferences (like 'would rather'), but it keeps the grammar of 'prefer' (it uses 'to + verb').
    Today I'd prefer to work from home.
  • Would Rather: For specific preferences, but always followed by the base verb (without 'to').
    It's noisy here. I'd rather work from home.

10 Examples with 'Would Rather':

  • (Simple preference) I'm tired. I'd rather stay home tonight.
  • (Comparison) I'd rather finish this now than leave it for tomorrow.
  • (Question) Would you rather have the meeting in the morning or afternoon?
  • (Negative) I'd rather not discuss this topic right now.
  • (Someone else's action - negative) I'd rather you didn't tell anyone about the project yet.
  • (Someone else's action - affirmative) She'd rather he called her back tomorrow.
  • (Technical choice) He'd rather use a simple text editor than a complex IDE.
  • (Question with options) Would they rather deploy on Friday or wait until Monday?
  • (Team negative) We'd rather not change the requirements again.
  • (Delegating) To be honest, I'd rather you handled this particular client.

42.title: Words ending in -ever
42.content:
Words like whatever, wherever, whenever, whoever are used to express the idea of 'any' or 'it doesn't matter which/where/when/who'.

Structure:

Verb + -ever word + clause

Examples:

  • Do whatever it takes to fix the problem.
  • You can deploy the code whenever you're ready.
  • We need to follow the style guide, however difficult it may seem.

43.title: As long as / Provided that
43.content:
These phrases are used to express a condition, similar to 'if'. They mean 'on the condition that'.

Structure:

Clause + as long as / provided that + Clause (Present)

Examples:

  • You can take the lead as long as you follow the project plan.
  • We can approve the change provided that it passes all the tests.
  • The feature will be included as long as we have enough time.

44.title: Either/Or and Neither/Nor
44.content:
These are correlative conjunctions. Either ... or ... connects two positive choices. Neither ... nor ... connects two negative options (the verb remains positive).

Structure:

either + option1 + or + option2
neither + option1 + nor + option2

Examples:

  • We can use either REST or GraphQL for this service.
  • Neither the developer nor the manager was available.
  • The bug is neither in the front-end nor in the back-end.

45.title: Reported Speech: Statements
45.content:
Reported Speech (or Indirect Speech) is used to report what someone else said without quoting them directly. The core principle is shifting the perspective to the past, which requires three key changes:

The 3 Key Changes:

  1. Tense Backshifting: The verb tense 'shifts back' one step into the past. This is the most important rule.
  2. Pronoun/Possessive Changes: Pronouns are adjusted to fit the new perspective (e.g., 'I' becomes 'he/she', 'my' becomes 'his/her').
  3. Time/Place Adverb Changes: Words like 'today' become 'that day', 'tomorrow' becomes 'the next day', and 'here' becomes 'there'.

Tense Transformation Table:

Direct Speech TenseReported Speech Tense
Present Simple
'The API is ready.'		Past Simple
He said the API was ready.
Present Continuous
'I am working on it.'		Past Continuous
She said she was working on it.
Past Simple
'We finished yesterday.'		Past Perfect
They said they had finished the day before.
Present Perfect
'I have fixed the bug.'		Past Perfect
He said he had fixed the bug.
Future (will)
'I will deploy it tomorrow.'		Conditional (would)
She said she would deploy it the next day.
Modal (can)
'I can solve this.'		Modal (could)
He said he could solve that.
Past Perfect
'The script had already run.'		Past Perfect (No Change)
They said the script had already run.

46.title: Reported Speech: Questions
46.content:
When reporting questions, the sentence structure changes from a question (with inversion) to a statement. The verb tense also 'shifts back' just like with statements.

Yes/No Questions:

Use 'if' or 'whether'. The word order becomes: Subject + Verb.

  • Direct: 'Are you finished?'
    → Reported: He asked if I was finished.
  • Direct: 'Does it have a cache?'
    → Reported: She asked whether it had a cache.
  • Direct: 'Have you pushed the changes?'
    → Reported: They asked if I had pushed the changes.

Wh- Questions:

Use the original question word (what, where, when, why, how). The word order also becomes: Subject + Verb.

  • Direct: 'Where is the file?'
    → Reported: She asked where the file was.
  • Direct: 'What did you change?'
    → Reported: He asked what I had changed.
  • Direct: 'When will the meeting start?'
    → Reported: They asked when the meeting would start.

47.title: Infinitive of Purpose
47.content:
To explain the purpose or reason for an action, we use the infinitive with 'to'. It is a concise way to answer the question 'Why?'.

Structure:

... Action + to + Base Verb ...

Examples:

  • I called a meeting to discuss the new requirements.
  • He wrote a script to automate the deployment process.
  • We need to run more tests to ensure quality.

48.title: Singular 'They'
48.content:
In modern English, it is grammatically correct to use 'they' as a singular, gender-neutral pronoun when a person's gender is unknown, irrelevant, or non-binary.

Structure:

Singular antecedent ... they/them/their

Examples:

  • If a developer has a question, they should ask their team lead.
  • Someone left their laptop in the meeting room.
  • The new manager is great; I really like them.

49.title: Prepositions: For vs. Of
49.content:
Of generally shows possession, belonging, or parts of a whole. For generally shows purpose, reason, or a beneficiary.

Structure:

Noun + of + Noun (Possession) | Noun + for + Noun (Purpose)

Examples:

  • This is the name of the file.
  • This is a fix for the issue.
  • We need the results of the test.

50.title: Question Formation (with Auxiliaries)
50.content:
Most questions in simple present and past require an auxiliary verb (do/does/did) before the subject. This is called inversion.

Structure:

(Wh-) + Auxiliary + Subject + Base Verb?

Examples:

  • What do you think?
  • Why did the build fail?
  • Do you have the latest version?

51.title: Subject-Verb Agreement in Questions
51.content:
When forming questions with 'do' and 'does', the verb must agree with the subject. The main verb stays in its base form.

Structure:

Do/Does + Subject + Base Verb?

Examples:

  • Do these logs contain the data? ('logs' is plural)
  • Does this change apply to QA? ('change' is singular)
  • Does the latest report include the new data? ('report' is singular)

52.title: Transitive vs. Intransitive Verbs
52.content:
Transitive verbs need a direct object to complete their meaning (the action passes to something/someone). Intransitive verbs do not need an object; the action is complete on its own.

Structure:

Transitive: Subject + Verb + Object
Intransitive: Subject + Verb

Examples:

  • She wrote the code. (Transitive)
  • The program runs. (Intransitive)
  • We discussed the issue. (Transitive)

53.title: Verbs of Motion (Manner vs. Path)
53.content:
Manner verbs (go, walk, drive) express *how* you move and need a preposition like 'to' for the destination. Path verbs (enter, attend, reach) include the destination and do not use 'to'.

Structure:

Manner: ... go to the office.
Path: ... enter the office.

Examples:

  • I need to go to the meeting.
  • He entered the building.
  • She attends the daily sync. (Incorrect: attends to the daily sync)

54.title: Reflexive Pronouns
54.content:
Used when the subject and the object of the verb are the same person. The action 'reflects' back on the subject. The pronouns are myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, themselves.

Structure:

Subject + Verb + Reflexive Pronoun

Examples:

  • I taught myself how to code.
  • The script updates itself automatically.
  • You should give yourself a break.

55.title: Future: Will vs. Going To
55.content:
Will is used for spontaneous decisions, predictions, or promises. Be going to is for pre-existing plans or intentions.

Structure:

Subject + will + Base Verb
Subject + be + going to + Base Verb

Examples:

  • (Spontaneous) The server is down? I will check it.
  • (Plan) I am going to refactor this module tomorrow.
  • (Prediction) This query will be slow without an index.

56.title: Past Perfect Continuous
56.content:
Used for an action that was in progress for a period of time before another action in the past. It emphasizes the duration of the 'past of the past' action.

Structure:

Subject + had been + Verb-ing

Examples:

  • I had been trying to fix it for hours when I found the solution.
  • She had been working on that feature long before the requirements changed.
  • They had been waiting for the API response for over a minute before it timed out.

57.title: Past Habits: 'Used to' vs. 'Would'
57.content:
Both used to and would are used to talk about repeated actions or habits in the past that are no longer true now. However, they have one very important difference.

Using 'Used to'

'Used to' can describe both past actions (e.g., play, go, work) and past states (e.g., be, have, live, believe).

Subject + used to + Base Verb

Using 'Would'

'Would' is only used for past actions. It cannot be used to describe past states. It often has a more nostalgic or story-telling tone.

Subject + would + Base Verb

The Key Difference: Actions vs. States

This is the most important rule. For actions, you can often use both. For states, you can only use 'used to'.

  • State (Correct): I used to live in a small town.
  • State (Incorrect): I would live in a small town.

Examples:

  • When I was a kid, my dad would read me a story every night. (Action)
  • We used to go to the beach every summer. (Action)
  • I used to have long hair. (State)
  • She used to be very shy. (State)
  • Every winter, they would build a snowman in the yard. (Action)
  • He didn't use to like coffee, but now he loves it. (Negative state)
  • There used to be a movie theater on this street. (State of existence)
  • Before I got this job, I would wake up late every day. (Action)
  • Did you use to play an instrument? (Question about a past habit)
  • My grandfather would always tell the same jokes. (Action)

59.title: Basic Modal Verbs
59.content:
Modal verbs add meaning like ability, obligation, or advice to a main verb. They are followed by a base verb and do not change form for the subject.

Structure:

Subject + modal + Base Verb

Examples:

  • (Advice) You should test your code.
  • (Ability) I can fix this bug quickly.
  • (Obligation) You must update the documentation.

60.title: Imperative Sentences
60.content:
The imperative form is used to give commands, orders, or instructions directly to someone. It is formed using the base verb without a subject.

Structure:

(Don't) + Base Verb + (Object)

Examples:

  • Commit your changes before pulling.
  • Run the tests again.
  • Don't forget to update the ticket.

61.title: Existential 'There' (There is/are)
61.content:
This structure is used to state the existence or presence of something. The verb ('is', 'are', 'was', 'were', etc.) must agree with the noun that follows.

Structure:

There + be (conjugated) + Noun

Examples:

  • There is a bug in the login page.
  • There are two new tickets in the queue.
  • There might be a problem with the server.

62.title: Want/Need + Object + Infinitive
62.content:
This structure is used to express that the subject desires or requires another person to perform an action. It's a common way to express requests or expectations.

Structure:

Subject + want/need/ask + Object + to + Verb

Examples:

  • The client wants us to add a new button.
  • I need you to review this code.
  • She asked him to update the documentation.

63.title: Noun Clauses (What... is...)
63.content:
A noun clause is a clause that functions as a noun. Using 'what' at the beginning of a sentence is a common way to create a noun clause and add emphasis to the main point.

Structure:

What + Subject + Verb + is + Main Point

Examples:

  • What I need is more time to test this.
  • What he suggested was a complete redesign.
  • What is blocking the progress is the lack of clear requirements.

64.title: Gerund as Subject
64.content:
The gerund (-ing form of a verb) can act as the subject of a sentence. When used this way, it is always treated as singular.

Structure:

Verb-ing + (Object) + Verb (singular) ...

Examples:

  • Testing the application is essential for quality.
  • Refactoring old code takes a lot of time.
  • Learning a new framework can be challenging.

65.title: Zero Conditional
65.content:
The Zero Conditional is used for general truths, facts, and scientific laws. It describes a result that always happens if a condition is met.

Structure:

If/When + Present Simple, ... Present Simple

Examples:

  • If you click this button, it opens a modal.
  • If the server receives too many requests, it gets slow.
  • When a user enters the wrong password, the system shows an error message.
  • If water reaches 100 degrees Celsius, it boils.
  • Plants die if they don't get enough water.
  • When I have a lot of work, I get stressed.

66.title: Prepositions at the End of Questions
66.content:
In modern English, especially in conversation, it is very common and natural to end a question with a preposition. This often happens with Wh- questions.

Structure:

Wh- + Aux + Subj + Verb + Preposition?

Examples:

  • What ticket are you working on?
  • Who did you talk to?
  • Which server should I connect to?

67.title: 'How long has it been since...?'
67.content:
This fixed structure is used to ask about the amount of time that has passed from a past event until now. The clause after 'since' must use the Past Simple.

Structure:

How long has it been since + Subject + Past Simple Verb?

Examples:

  • How long has it been since you cleared the cache?
  • How long has it been since we last updated this library?
  • (Incorrect: ...since you don't clear the cache?)

68.title: Collective Nouns
68.content:
Collective nouns (e.g., team, company, family) refer to a group. In American English, they are usually treated as singular, taking a singular verb.

Structure:

Collective Noun (as unit) + Verb (singular)

Examples:

  • The team is ready for the next sprint.
  • Our company has a new policy.
  • However, words like 'police' and 'people' are always plural.

69.title: Extreme (Non-Gradable) Adjectives
69.content:
Some adjectives are 'extreme' and already imply 'very'. We don't use 'very' with them. Instead, we use intensifiers like 'absolutely', 'completely', or 'totally'.

Structure:

(Gradable): very + tired/big/good
(Extreme): absolutely + exhausted/huge/brilliant

Examples:

  • After the release, I was absolutely exhausted.
  • The new database is completely huge.
  • Her solution was absolutely brilliant.

70.title: Prepositional Adjectives
70.content:
Many adjectives must be followed by a specific preposition to be grammatically correct. These combinations should be learned as fixed phrases.

Structure:

... Adjective + Preposition

Examples:

  • I'm responsible for deploying the changes.
  • She is good at solving complex problems.
  • This component is similar to the old one.

71.title: Separable Phrasal Verbs
71.content:
Many phrasal verbs are 'separable', meaning the object can go between the verb and the particle. If the object is a pronoun (it, them, me), it must go in the middle.

Structure:

Verb + Object + Particle

Examples:

  • Please turn the server on. / Please turn on the server.
  • Correct: Please turn it on.
  • Incorrect: Please turn on it.

72.title: Indefinite Pronouns (Everyone, Nobody)
72.content:
Indefinite pronouns like 'everyone', 'everybody', 'someone', 'somebody', 'nobody', 'no one' are always treated as singular and take a singular verb.

Structure:

Indefinite Pronoun + Verb (singular)

Examples:

  • Everyone is in the meeting. (Not 'are')
  • Somebody has to fix this bug. (Not 'have')
  • Nobody knows the root cause yet. (Not 'know')

73.title: Comparisons of Equality (as...as)
73.content:
To say that two things are equal in some quality, we use the structure 'as + adjective/adverb + as'. In negative sentences, 'not as...as' or 'not so...as' can be used.

Structure:

... as + Adjective/Adverb + as ...

Examples:

  • The new API is as fast as the old one.
  • This task is not as difficult as it looks.
  • He can code as quickly as she can.

74.title: Inversion for Emphasis
74.content:
In formal English, we can invert the subject and auxiliary verb for emphasis after a negative adverb (e.g., Never, Not only, Rarely, Hardly). This creates a more dramatic effect.

Structure:

Negative Adverb + Auxiliary + Subject + Verb

Examples:

  • Never before have I seen such clean code.
  • Not only did he fix the bug, but he also improved performance.
  • Rarely do we get a chance to work on a greenfield project.

75.title: Cleft Sentences (It is... that...)
75.content:
Cleft sentences split a single clause into two to emphasize a specific piece of information. The 'It is...' or 'It was...' structure is very common for emphasizing the subject or object.

Structure:

It is/was + Emphasized Part + that/who + ...

Examples:

  • Normal: 'John deployed the feature.' -> Emphatic: It was John who deployed the feature.
  • Normal: 'We need to fix the UI.' -> Emphatic: It is the UI that we need to fix.
  • Normal: 'The bug appeared yesterday.' -> Emphatic: It was yesterday that the bug appeared.

76.title: Participle Adjectives (-ed vs. -ing)
76.content:
Verb participles can be used as adjectives. The -ing form describes the thing that causes the feeling (it is active). The -ed form describes the person or thing that has the feeling (it is passive).

Structure:

The task is confusing. (It causes confusion)
I am confused. (I feel confusion)

Examples:

  • The long meeting was boring.
  • The developers were bored by the long meeting.
  • This is an interesting problem. I am interested in finding a solution.

77.title: Agreement with 'So' and 'Too'
77.content:
To agree with a positive statement, use 'So + auxiliary + I' or 'I + auxiliary + too'. The auxiliary must match the tense of the original statement.

Structure:

So + Auxiliary + Subject
Subject + Auxiliary + too

Examples:

  • A: 'I have finished my task.' -> B: 'So have I.' / 'I have too.'
  • A: 'She works in the QA team.' -> B: 'So do I.'
  • A: 'The server was down.' -> B: 'So was the other one.'

78.title: Exclamations with 'What a' and 'How'
78.content:
To make exclamations, use What a/an... before a (adjective +) singular countable noun, and How... before an adjective or adverb.

Structure:

What a/an + (Adj) + Noun!
How + Adjective/Adverb!

Examples:

  • What a terrible bug!
  • What an elegant solution!
  • How inefficient this query is!
  • How quickly he works!

79.title: Prepositional Verbs
79.content:
Prepositional Verbs are verbs that require a specific preposition to connect with their object. The verb and preposition form a fixed phrase with a specific meaning.

Structure:

Subject + Verb + Preposition + Object

Examples:

  • You should apologize for your mistake.
  • We need to concentrate on the main goal.
  • Are you listening to me?

80.title: Preferences: 'Prefer' vs. 'Would Prefer'
80.content:
While both express preference, they are used in different contexts. The main distinction is general habits vs. specific situations.

'Prefer' (General Preferences)

Use prefer to talk about habits or what you like in general. It follows two main patterns:

1. Comparing nouns/activities:
prefer + [Noun/Verb-ing] + to + [Noun/Verb-ing]

2. Stating a preference:
prefer + [to + Verb] OR [Verb-ing]

'Would Prefer' (Specific Preferences)

Use would prefer (or 'd prefer) for a choice in a specific situation, right now or in the near future. It is more polite and formal than 'want'.

'd prefer + [to + Verb]

Quick Note: The 'Would Rather' Difference

'Would rather' is also for specific preferences, but it is always followed by the base verb (without 'to').
• Compare: I'd prefer to go. vs. I'd rather go.

10 Examples:

  • (General) She generally prefers coffee to tea.
  • (Specific) Thanks for the offer, but tonight I'd prefer to stay home.
  • (General) I prefer working in a team to working alone.
  • (Specific Question) Would you prefer to have the meeting now or later?
  • (General) Many developers prefer to use dark mode.
  • (Specific Negative) He'd prefer not to discuss the issue right now.
  • (General) For this project, they prefer Python to Java.
  • (Specific & Polite) Where would you prefer to sit?
  • (General Negative) I don't prefer spicy food.
  • (Specific) We'd prefer to finish the deployment before we leave.

81.title: Impersonal Sentences
81.content:
Impersonal Sentences are used to make general statements, rules, or express opinions without a specific subject. Pronouns like it, you, they, and people are often used for this.

Structure:

Impersonal Pronoun + Verb ...

Examples:

  • It is important to stay hydrated.
  • In this company, you have to be proactive. (You = anyone)
  • They say this is the best restaurant in town. (They = people in general)

82.title: Connectors of Cause & Effect
82.content:
These words link a reason (cause) with a result (effect). Use because before a cause, and so or therefore before a result. Use because of before a noun.

Structure:

Effect + because + Cause
Cause + so/therefore + Effect

Examples:

  • He was late because there was traffic.
  • There was traffic, so he was late.
  • He was late because of the traffic.

83.title: Connectors for Adding Information
83.content:
These words and phrases are used to add more information to a statement. Their position in the sentence can vary.

Structure:

Sentence. Also/Besides, Sentence.
... and ... as well.

Examples:

  • The system is slow. Also, it has a few bugs.
  • Besides being slow, the system has a few bugs.
  • The system is slow, and it has a few bugs as well.

84.title: The Adverb 'Even' for Emphasis
84.content:
The adverb even is used to add emphasis, often to show something is surprising or unexpected. Not even is used to mean 'ni siquiera'.

Structure:

Even + Surprising element
Subject + negative aux + even + Verb

Examples:

  • Even the senior developer couldn't solve it.
  • This solution is even better.
  • He didn't even try to fix it.

85.title: 'Don't have to' vs. 'Mustn't'
85.content:
This is a critical distinction. Don't have to means there is no obligation (it's optional). Mustn't means there is a prohibition (it's forbidden).

Structure:

Subject + don't have to + Verb (No obligation)
Subject + mustn't + Verb (Prohibition)

Examples:

  • You don't have to come if you're busy.
  • You mustn't touch that button.

86.title: Questions: 'What... like?' vs. 'How is...?'
86.content:
Use What is ... like? to ask for a general description of characteristics. Use How is ...? to ask about a current, temporary state or condition (e.g., health, mood).

Structure:

What + be + Subject + like?
How + be + Subject?

Examples:

  • A: What is your new job like? B: It's challenging but interesting.
  • A: How is your new job? B: It's going well, thanks!

87.title: Compound Nouns: Open & Closed
87.content:
A Compound Noun is a single noun created from two or more words. This modal covers the two most common types: open (written separately) and closed (written as one word).

Pluralization Rule

For both open and closed compound nouns, the plural is almost always formed by adding -s to the very end of the complete word.

A) Open Compound Nouns (two words)

These are two separate words that function as a single unit.

  • The bus stop is just around the corner.
  • I can't find a parking space anywhere.
  • We're having dinner in the living room tonight.
  • You'll need your credit card to pay for that.
  • Is there a post office near here?

B) Closed Compound Nouns (one word)

These words have fused into a single word over time.

  • My keyboard stopped working, so I can't type.
  • Don't forget to pack your toothbrush before the trip.
  • I need to get some sunscreen before we go to the beach.
  • The kids are playing football outside.
  • Could you turn on the bedroom light, please?

88.title: Possessive Pronouns (mine, yours, etc.)
88.content:
A Possessive Pronoun replaces a possessive adjective + noun to avoid repetition. It stands alone and is not followed by a noun.

The pronouns are: mine, yours, his, hers, its, ours, theirs.

Structure:

... is + Possessive Pronoun.

Examples:

  • This isn't my code, it's yours.
  • Her design is good, but mine is simpler.
  • That computer is theirs.

89.title: Expressing States with 'to be'
89.content:
In English, physical sensations and feelings are described using the verb to be + adjective. This is a key difference from languages like Spanish, which often use 'tener'.

Structure:

Subject + be (conjugated) + Adjective

Examples:

  • I am hungry. (Not: I have hunger)
  • She is cold. (Not: She has cold)
  • They are thirsty.

90.title: Using 'Have Got' for Possession/Obligation
90.content:
In informal English (especially British English), have got is a very common alternative to have for possession, and have got to is used for have to (obligation).

Structure:

Subject + 've/'s got + Object
Subject + 've/'s got to + Verb

Examples:

  • I've got a question. (= I have)
  • She's got a new car. (= She has)
  • We've got to leave now. (= We have to)

91.title: Past Intentions: 'was/were going to'
91.content:
This structure is used to talk about plans, intentions, or predictions in the past that did not happen for some reason. It's the past tense of 'be going to'.

Structure:

Subject + was/were + going to + Base Verb

Examples:

  • I was going to do it, but I forgot.
  • She was going to call you, but her phone died.
  • They were going to launch the feature, but they found a critical bug.
  • He was going to tell you, but it wasn't necessary.
  • We were going to write it down, but we didn't know where.
  • It was going to be a sunny day, but then it started raining.

92.title: Idiomatic Expressions (Idioms)
92.content:
An idiom is a common phrase or expression whose meaning cannot be understood from the literal definition of its individual words. They are a type of figure of speech and must be learned as a whole unit.

Idioms do not fit into a single grammatical category; they can function as verbs, nouns, or entire clauses within a sentence.

Examples:

  • (To forget something) It completely slipped my mind.
  • (To face a difficult situation with courage) You just have to bite the bullet.
  • (Something is very easy) Don't worry, the test will be a piece of cake.
  • (A problem that seems bad at first but results in something good) Losing that job was a blessing in disguise.
  • (To study hard) I have to go home and hit the books.

93.title: Causative 'Have'
93.content:
The Causative 'Have' is used to show that the subject arranges for someone else to do something for them. It is the natural way to talk about services you pay for or actions you delegate.

For example, 'I cut my hair' implies you did it yourself. 'I had my hair cut' implies you went to a hairdresser. This structure is also used for negative events that happen *to* the subject.

Structure:

Subject + have (conjugated) + Object + Past Participle

Examples:

  • (Service) I'm going to have my hair cut tomorrow.
  • (Service) We are having our house painted next month.
  • (Service) She needs to have her eyes checked.
  • (Service) He has his windows cleaned once a month.
  • (Service) The company had a new app developed.
  • (Negative Event) I had my wallet stolen on the subway.

94.title: Mathematical Operations & Symbols
94.content:
In English, mathematical operations are expressed with specific words. Knowing these terms is essential for discussing calculations clearly.

Common Operations:

  • Addition (+)
    5 + 3 = 8 is read as 'five plus three equals eight'.
  • Subtraction (-)
    10 - 4 = 6 is read as 'ten minus four equals six'.
  • Multiplication (× or *)
    5 × 8 = 40 is read as 'five times eight is forty'. You can also say 'multiplied by'.
  • Division (÷ or /)
    20 ÷ 4 = 5 is read as 'twenty divided by four equals five'.
  • Equality (=)
    The symbol = is called the 'equals sign'. In speech, you can say 'equals' or 'is'.
  • Parentheses ()
    (2 + 3) × 4 is read as 'two plus three in parentheses, times four'.

95.title: Causative 'Get' (Get something done)
95.content:
The Causative 'Get' is used to show that the subject arranges for someone else to do something for them, often by paying for a service. It's a common and slightly more informal alternative to the 'Causative Have'.

The focus is on the action being completed, not on who performs it.

Structure:

Subject + get (conjugated) + Object + Past Participle

Examples:

  • I need to get my car fixed.
  • She got her phone repaired after she dropped it.
  • We are getting our house painted next week.
  • You should get your suit cleaned before the wedding.
  • Where can I get this document translated?
  • He got a pizza delivered for dinner.

96.title: Citing & Conditions: According to vs. Based on vs. Depending on
96.content:
These phrases are often confused but have distinct meanings for expressing sources, reasons, or conditions.

Key Differences:

  • According to... is used to cite a source of information. You are reporting what someone or something else has said.
    According to the weather forecast, it's going to rain tomorrow.
  • Based on... is used to explain the reason, evidence, or criteria for a decision or action.
    The team was chosen based on their performance.
  • Depending on... is used to show that a result or action is subject to a variable or condition.
    We might go to the park, depending on the weather.

More Examples:

  • [Citing Source] According to the article, the company is doing well.
  • [Stating Criteria] We organize the files based on the project name.
  • [Expressing Condition] The price can change depending on availability.

Common Error: Do not use 'according to me'. The correct phrase is 'in my opinion'.

97.title: Common Adjective + Gerund Structures
97.content:
A few common and practical English adjectives and expressions are followed directly by a Gerund (-ing form) instead of an infinitive. These structures must be memorized as fixed patterns.

Key Structures:

  • busy + doing something
    Used to say that you are occupied with an activity.
    She is busy preparing for her final exams.
  • worth + doing something
    Used to say that something is useful, enjoyable, or beneficial to do.
    The new feature is worth trying.
  • it's no use / it's no good + doing something
    Used to say that an action is pointless or will not have a successful result.
    It's no use complaining about the problem; we need to fix it.

More Examples:

  • I was too busy answering emails to join the call.
  • This museum is definitely worth visiting while you're in the city.
  • It's no good trying to convince him; his mind is made up.

98.title: Mixed Conditionals
98.content:
Mixed Conditionals combine parts of different conditional types, usually the Second and Third. They are used when the time of the condition is different from the time of the result. This creates a link between the past and the present, or the present and the past.

Type 1: Past Condition → Present Result

This type describes a hypothetical past action (that didn't happen) and its imaginary result in the present.

If + Past Perfect, ... would + Base Verb

  • If I had taken that job, I would be rich now.
  • You wouldn't be so tired if you had gone to bed earlier last night.
  • If we had bought the tickets, we would be at the concert right now.

Type 2: Present Condition → Past Result

This type describes a hypothetical present state (that isn't true) and its imaginary result in the past. This is less common.

If + Past Simple, ... would have + Past Participle

  • If I were a better programmer, I would have written that script myself.
  • If he wasn't so shy, he would have asked her out yesterday.
  • If I spoke French, I would have understood them at the meeting.

99.title: Compound Nouns: Hyphenated
99.content:
Hyphenated Compound Nouns use hyphens (-) to connect words, often to define roles, relationships, or to create a single, clear concept and avoid ambiguity.

The Plural Rule (Important!)

This is the key difference: the plural -s is added to the primary noun in the phrase, not to the end of the entire word. This is the most significant word in the compound.

Examples:

  • My mother-in-law is coming to visit for the weekend.
  • He is the editor-in-chief of a famous newspaper.
  • A passer-by found the lost wallet on the street.

Plural Examples in Action:

  • I have three sisters-in-law, and they are all very nice.
  • Several passers-by stopped to help after the accident.
  • The newspaper has had many editors-in-chief over the years.

100.title: Talking About Money: North America & Beyond
100.content:
Understanding how to talk about money in English involves knowing both the formal terms and the common, everyday slang. This guide focuses on the practical language used in the USA and Canada.

North America (USA & Canada)

The system and language are nearly identical in both countries.

  • Currency: The main unit is the Dollar, and the subunit is the Cent. The decimal separator is always a period (e.g., $10.50).
  • Key Slang: The most common informal word for 'dollar' is buck (singular) or bucks (plural).
  • Saying Prices: For a price like $4.99, the most natural way to say it is 'four ninety-nine'. The words 'dollars' and 'cents' are usually omitted.
  • Canada Specific: Informally, Canadians sometimes use 'Loonie' for the one-dollar coin and 'Toonie' for the two-dollar coin.

Bonus: Contrast with UK & Europe

  • United Kingdom: Currency is the Pound (£), with the slang term quid. The subunit is Pence (p). £10.50 is said 'ten pounds fifty' or 'ten fifty'.
  • Eurozone: Currency is the Euro (€). €10.50 is 'ten euros fifty'. Many European countries use a comma as a decimal separator in writing (10,50€).

10 Common Examples (US/Canada):

  • The total comes to twenty-five fifty.
  • Do you have anything for around ten bucks?
  • A coffee here costs about three seventy-five.
  • Can I borrow a couple of bucks for the vending machine?
  • You owe me twenty bucks from dinner last night.
  • This shirt is on sale—it's only twelve ninety-nine.
  • All I have is a fifty-dollar bill; do you have change?
  • The tickets were a hundred and fifty dollars each. (formal/emphatic)
  • Is it possible to pay in cash?
  • I'm trying to save some money for my vacation.
